title: Ahmad Tasnim
text:
<a href="Vice-Admiral">Vice-Admiral</a> Ahmad Tasnim (<a href="Urdu">Urdu</a>:احمد تسنيم; born 1935), , is a retired <a href="Three-star%20rank">three-star</a> rank <a href="admiral">admiral</a> in the <a href="Pakistan%20Navy">Pakistan Navy</a> who is notable for his command of the <a href="PNS%20Hangor">"Hangor"</a>, a <a href="Hangor-class%20submarine%20%281968%29">submarine</a>, that sank the <a href="INS%20Khukri%20%281958%29">INS Khukri</a> on 8 December 1971 during the <a href="Indo-Pakistani%20War%20of%201971">third war</a> with India, off the <a href="Diu%2C%20India">Diu</a>, <a href="Gujarat">Gujarat</a> in <a href="India">India</a>.
This was the first submarine kill since <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, and the only one until a <a href="Royal%20Navy">Royal Navy</a>'s <a href="HMS%20Conqueror%20%28S48%29">"Conqueror"</a> sank an <a href="Argentina">Argentine</a> cruiser <a href="ARA%20General%20Belgrano">"General Belgrano"</a> during the <a href="Falklands%20War">Falklands War</a> fought in 1980s. In 1990s, he was appointed chairman of the <a href="Karachi%20Port%20Trust">Karachi Port Trust</a> and the <a href="Pakistan%20National%20Shipping%20Corporation">Pakistan National Shipping Corporation</a> while serving in the Navy until retiring from his service in 1994.
Biography.
Early life and career in Navy.
In an interview conducted by A.H. Amin, Ahmad Tasnim stated that he was born in a village, Mianwal, located in <a href="Jalandhar%20district">Jalandhar district</a>, <a href="East%20Punjab">East Punjab</a> in <a href="British%20Indian%20Empire">British India</a>, in 1935. In the same interview, he stated that his ancestors "most likely came from <a href="Iran">Iran</a>" and "took up agriculture as their livelihood" after settling in the "area".
His father, <a href="Choudri%20Muhammad%20Yaqub">Mohammad Yakob</a>, was a civil servant with <a href="Indian%20Civil%20Service%20%28British%20India%29">Indian Civil Service</a> of British government. In 1940, he moved with his father who was posted to <a href="Jhang">Jhang</a> in <a href="Punjab%2C%20Pakistan">West Punjab</a> and permanently moved to <a href="Burewala">Burewala</a> after the <a href="Independence%20of%20Pakistan">independence</a> of <a href="Pakistan">Pakistan</a> on <a href="Fourteenth%20of%20August">14 August</a> as result of the <a href="Partition%20of%20India">partition</a> of <a href="India">India</a>.
After matriculating from a local high school in Jhang, he was admitted at the <a href="Government%20College%20University%20%28Lahore%29">Government College University</a> in <a href="Lahore">Lahore</a> in 1950 but left his university studies after being selected for the military service exam in 1952. In 1954, he joined the <a href="Pakistan%20Navy">Pakistan Navy</a>, <a href="Commissioned%20officer">commissioned</a> as <a href="Midshipman">Midshipman</a> and was sent to the <a href="United%20Kingdom">United Kingdom</a> to attend the <a href="Britannia%20Royal%20Naval%20College">Britannia Royal Naval College</a> in <a href="Dartmouth%2C%20Devon">Dartmouth</a>, England. He shared his dormitory with <a href="Cadet">army cadet</a> <a href="Imran%20Ullah%20Khan">Imranullah Khan</a> who would also ascended into being a three-star army general. He graduated from the <a href="Britannia%20Royal%20Naval%20College">Britannia Royal Naval College</a> in 1955, and was later sent to <a href="Australia">Australia</a> for further sea training where he joined the <a href="Royal%20Australian%20Navy">Royal Australian Navy</a> as an <a href="exchange%20officer">exchange officer</a>, gaining commission as <a href="Sub%20Lieutenant">Sub-Lieutenant</a> on 1 January 1957, and served aboard <a href="HMAS%20Sydney%20%28R17%29">HMAS Sydney</a>, an <a href="aircraft%20carrier">aircraft carrier</a>.
Briefly serving as an <a href="exchange%20officer">exchange officer</a>, <a href="Sub%20Lieutenant">S/Lt.</a> Tasnim was again set to <a href="England">England</a> where he attended the <a href="Royal%20Naval%20College%2C%20Greenwich">Royal Naval College</a> in <a href="Greenwich">Greenwich</a>, where he graduated in <a href="War%20studies">War studies</a> with strong emphasis on <a href="nuclear%20war">nuclear war</a>. Upon returning to Pakistan, he was promoted as <a href="Lieutenant%20%28naval%29">lieutenant</a>, and was posted as <a href="executive%20officer">executive officer</a> to which he served until 1961. During this time, he was posted in <a href="East%20Pakistan">East Pakistan</a> but return shortly after <a href="Lieutenant%20%28naval%29">Lt.</a> Tasnim was appointed as <a href="Aide-de-camp">ADC</a> to <a href="President%20of%20Pakistan">President</a> <a href="Ayub%20Khan%20%28general%29">Ayub Khan</a>.
In 1963, <a href="Lieutenant%20%28naval%29">Lt.</a> Tasnim personally excused himself from his assignment in order to join the newly established crew that was to be trained in the <a href="United%20States">United States</a> in order to operate the <a href="PNS%20Ghazi">submarine acquired</a> from the <a href="United%20States%20Navy">United States Navy</a>. Alongside with then-<a href="Lieutenant-Commander">Lt.Cdr</a> <a href="Karamat%20Rahman%20Niazi">K.R. Niazi</a>, <a href="Lieutenant%20%28naval%29">Lt.</a> Tasnim arrived in the <a href="New%20London%2C%20Connecticut">New London</a> in <a href="Connecticut">Connecticut</a> where he was trained on the <a href="USS%20Angler">USS Angler</a> for the submarine operations. In 1964, the crew of <a href="PNS%20Ghazi">"Ghazi"</a> returned to Pakistan and reported back to its base, <a href="Karachi%20Naval%20Dockyard">Karachi Naval Dockyard</a>.
War appointments in Navy: 1965 and 1971 war.
In 1965, <a href="Lieutenant-Commander">Lieutenant-Commander</a> Tasnim was the <a href="Executive%20Officer">executive officer</a> and <a href="Second-in-Command">Second-in-Command</a> of the , and participated in <a href="Indo-Pakistani%20war%20of%201965">second war</a> with <a href="India">India</a> in 1965.
"Ghazi", under command of <a href="Commander%20%28rank%29">Cdr</a> <a href="Karamat%20Rahman%20Niazi">KR Niazi</a>, escorted the <a href="Flotilla">combined task group</a> under <a href="Commodore%20%28rank%29">Cdre</a> S.M. Anwar, the <a href="Officer%20in%20tactical%20command">OTC</a>, to successfully <a href="Operation%20Dwarka">raid a radar facility</a> in <a href="Dwarka">Dwarka</a>, <a href="India">India</a>. "Ghazi" later patrolled the <a href="Arabian%20Sea">Arabian sea</a> and reported back safely to its base once the <a href="Tashkent%20Agreement">ceasefire</a> was broken by the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a> between <a href="India%20and%20Pakistan">India and Pakistan</a>. Lt. Cdr. Tasnim was honoured with <a href="Sitara-e-Jurat">Sitara-e-Jurat</a>, alongside with the "Ghazi" in 1966.
In 1967, <a href="Lieutenant-Commander">Lieutenant-Commander</a> Tasnim assumed the <a href="Commanding%20officer">command</a> of "Ghazi" and became concerned for her <a href="refit">refit</a> as time passed. After refitting of its computers, "Ghazi" under the command of <a href="Lieutenant-Commander">Lt. Cdr.</a> Tasnim embarked on the notable <a href="circumnavigation">circumnavigation</a> of <a href="Africa">Africa</a> and <a href="Southern%20Europe">Southern Europe</a> in order for its <a href="mid-life%20update">mid-life update</a> that were to be carried out in <a href="G%C3%B6lc%C3%BCk%20Naval%20Shipyard">Gölcük Naval Shipyard</a> in <a href="Turkey">Turkey</a> due to the closure of the <a href="Suez%20Canal">Suez Canal</a> because of the <a href="Six-Day%20War">Six-Day War</a>.
After the refit trials, Lt. Cdr. Tasnim returned to <a href="Karachi">Karachi</a> and traveled to <a href="Paris">Paris</a> to acquire the . There, he learned <a href="French%20language">French</a> language and took over of the command of the in 1969 as Commander.
Cdr. Tasnim arrived with "Hangor" submarines in 1970, and reported to its base in Karachi on 1 December 1970. On August 1971, Cdr. Tasnim volunteered to go behind the enemy lines to pick up intelligence on <a href="Indian%20Navy">Indian Navy</a>'s movement, which was duly approved. On November 1971, again sailed under his command with full wartime load of <a href="torpedoes">torpedoes</a>, moving towards <a href="Mumbai">Bombay harbour</a>, identifying the Indian armada but did not attack due to not being authorized. In an attempt to warn, Cdr. Tasnim broke the radio silence and dispatched a message that was immediately identified, leading the Indian Navy dispatching two <a href="anti-submarine%20warfare">ASW warships</a>, and INS "Kirpan" from <a href="Squadron%20%28naval%29">14th Squadron</a> of the <a href="Western%20Naval%20Command">Western Naval Command</a> of the <a href="Indian%20Navy">Indian Navy</a>. The Indian squadron under <a href="Captain%20%28naval%29">Captain</a> <a href="Mahendra%20Nath%20Mulla">M.N. Mullah</a> identified "Hangor" on 2–3 December, and came forward to attack the submarine that was operating on the <a href="Waves%20and%20shallow%20water">shallow waters</a>. Cdr. Tasnim ordered the increase of depth of the submarine by 200 m and set their targets on approaching Indian Navy's ship that were now coming to attack the submarine.
At about 20:00Hrs, Cdr. Tasnim had his torpedo crew led by then-<a href="Lieutenant%20%28naval%29">Lt.</a> <a href="Fasih%20Bokhari">Fasih Bokhari</a> calculate the enemy ship path and firing range, and order the crew to fire the torpedoes. The first <a href="homing%20torpedo">homing torpedo</a> did not target its ship which was aimed at "Kirpan", and immediately opted a quick solution, firing second <a href="homing%20torpedo">homing torpedo</a> that hit the magazine of the "Khukri". The crew of "Hangor" heard a loud explosion and began recording the orders being passed by Captain <a href="Mahendra%20Nath%20Mulla">M.N. Mullah</a>; a third homing torpedo was also fired but "Kirpan" fled the scene. "Khukri" sank quickly before "Hangor" could make an attempt to save the survivors, losing 250 men in this action including Captain M.N. Mullah.
For almost a week, Cdr. Tasnim had the "Hangor" submerged due to being aware of massive search and destroy mission to locate "Hangor", making his way to report back to its base with depleted <a href="Nickel%E2%80%93hydrogen%20battery">hydrogen batteries</a>. According to his personal admission in 2001, Tasnim maintained: ""An extensive air search combined with surface ships made our life miserable but with intelligent evasive action we managed to survive these attacks and arrived in Karachi safely after the ceasefire"."
Staff and Command appointments.
Upon returning to Pakistan, Cdr. Tasnim was decorated with <a href="Sitara-e-Jurat">Sitara-e-Jurat</a> for his actions of valour in 1972. In 1973, he was posted in <a href="NHQ%20%28Pakistan%20Navy%29">Navy NHQ</a> in <a href="Islamabad">Islamabad</a>, becoming director submarine operations and assuming the command of submarine command (COMSUBS) in 1974. In 1975–76, Cdr. Tasnim went to <a href="United%20States">United States</a> to attend the <a href="U.%20S.%20Naval%20War%20College">Naval War College</a> in <a href="Rhode%20Island">Rhode Island</a>, returning with <a href="Master%20of%20Science">MSc.</a> in war studies, and appointed "Directing Staff" at the <a href="Pakistan%20Naval%20War%20College">Naval War College</a> in <a href="Karachi">Karachi</a>.
In 1976, he was promoted to <a href="One-star%20rank">one-star</a> assignment, and <a href="Captain%20%28naval%29">Capt.</a> Tasnim was appointed as Director-General Naval Operations (DGNO) and then <a href="Naval%20Secretary">Naval Secretary</a> at <a href="NHQ%20%28Pakistan%20Navy%29">Navy NHQ</a> in <a href="Islamabad">Islamabad</a>. In 1978, <a href="Commodore%20%28rank%29">Cdre.</a> was selected by the <a href="Ministry%20of%20Defence%20%28Pakistan%29">Ministry of Defence</a> (MoD) for a diplomatic assignment, and briefly tenured as <a href="military%20attach%C3%A9">military attaché</a> at the <a href="List%20of%20diplomatic%20missions%20of%20Pakistan">Embassy of Pakistan</a> in <a href="Paris">Paris</a> until 1981.
Upon returning, Cdre. Tasnim was tactical officer commanding of the 25th Destroyer Squadron, later commandant of the <a href="Pakistan%20Naval%20War%20College">Naval War College</a> in <a href="Karachi">Karachi</a> and posted as the <a href="Assistant%20Chief%20of%20the%20Naval%20Staff">ACNS (Training)</a> until promoted to <a href="Two-star%20admiral">two-star</a> rank. In 1984, <a href="Rear-Admiral">Rear-Admiral</a> Tasnim was directed to join the faculty of <a href="National%20Defence%20University%2C%20Pakistan">National Defence University</a> (NDU) in <a href="Islamabad">Islamabad</a>, teaching courses on military studies of which then-<a href="Brigadier">Brig.</a> <a href="Pervez%20Musharraf">Pervez Musharraf</a> was also this student. He remained <a href="Full%20Professor">Chief Instructor (CI)</a> at the <a href="National%20Defence%20University%2C%20Pakistan">NDU</a> until 1987.
In 1987–88, Rear-Admiral Tasnim was appointed as <a href="Deputy%20Chief%20of%20the%20Naval%20Staff%20%28Pakistan%29">DCNS (Personnel)</a> and later became a senior <a href="Fleet%20Commander">fleet commander</a> in 1989–91, with as three-star rank, <a href="Vice-Admiral">Vice-Admiral</a>.
In 1991, <a href="Vice-Admiral">Vice-Admiral</a> Tasnim's name was announced to be appointed as <a href="Chairman">Chairman</a> of the <a href="Pakistan%20National%20Shipping%20Corporation">National Shipping Corporation</a> which he stayed until 1992. In 1992, Vice-Admiral Tasnim was moved as chairman of <a href="Karachi%20Port%20Trust">Karachi Port Trust</a> (KPT), which he remained until his retirement from the Navy in 1994. In 1992, Vice-Admiral Tasnim was moved as chairman of <a href="Karachi%20Port%20Trust">Karachi Port Trust</a> (KPT), which he remained until his retirement from the Navy in 1994.
Retirement and defence analyst.
In 2001, Admiral Tasnim refuted the Indian Navy's claim of sinking the <a href="PNS%20Ghazi">"Ghazi"</a>, maintaining on the ground that "the sub was lost due to operational accident and Indians have never claimed it as such."
In 2016, Admiral Tasnim backed the <a href="Inter-Services%20Public%20Relations">ISPR</a>'s claim of detecting the Indian Navy's submarine patrol the <a href="Karachi%20coast">Karachi coast</a>, claiming that: the Indian submarine was detected 40 nautical miles off Pakistani coast." Talking to <a href="Dawn%20%28newspaper%29">"Dawn"</a>, Tasnim was of the opinion that ""the submarine had come for intelligence gathering purposes. Intelligence gathering is a common practice, but the skill is not to get caught – like we did in our times"."
Portrayal.
In December 2021, <a href="ARY%20Digital">ARY Digital</a> release a telefilm "<a href="Hangor%20S-131">Hangor S-131</a>", based on real incidents from 1971 Indo-Pak war in which role of Tasnim was played by <a href="Zahid%20Ahmed%20%28actor%29">Zahid Ahmed</a>.
